questions.question: Question 1: Homeostasis is called as dynamic equilibrium because

options.a: All variables are given equal importance
options.b: Can achieve a constancy in extreme environmental challenge
options.c: The set-point for all homeostatic variables is always fixed
options.d: Body maintains an internal balance within fluctuating limits

questions.explanation:
Homeostasis is called dynamic equilibrium because the body maintains an internal balance within 
fluctuating limits. It describes the maintenance of nearly constant conditions in the internal 
environment despite changes in the outside world. A number of variables such as body temperature, blood sugar levels, blood pH, etc. are regulated 
within a range of values (homeostatic ranges) and not at fixed values. These variables are not given equal importance. There is a hierarchy of importance so that the 
constancy of certain variables may be altered markedly to maintain others within their normal 
range. For example, respiratory or metabolic compensation to maintain blood pH. The disruption of homeostasis either due to extreme environmental challenge or a breakdown of 
internal homeostatic mechanisms is termed as a disease.

questions.question: Question 2: Which is a component of homeostatic control system?
questions.explanation:
Stimulus, receptor and effector are all components of a homeostatic control system. Components of homeostasis include: • Stimulus - It is a detectable change in the internal or external environment, such as change in 
temperature. • Receptor - It detects environmental changes. • Integrating centre • Effector - It is an organ or cell that acts in response to a stimulus. 11 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Feedback regulation is seen in

options.a: The increased heart rate that occurs in an athlete just before a sprint begins
options.b: Smell of food triggers secretion of salivary and gastric juices
options.c: An increase in insulin before glucose absorption has raised blood glucose levels
options.d: The increased heart rate in response to a decrease in blood pressure

questions.explanation:
Feedback regulation is seen in the increased heart rate in response to a decrease in blood 
pressure. This is because, in feedback regulation, the homeostatic response (increased heart rate) 
occurs after the change (decrease in blood pressure) has occurred. On the other hand, in feedforward regulation, the homeostatic responses take place before the 
change has occurred. This is done in anticipation of the change to minimize fluctuations. 
Examples of feedforward regulation include: • The increased heart rate that occurs in an athlete just before a sprint begins. • The smell of food triggers the secretion of salivary and gastric juices. • An increase in insulin before glucose absorption has raised blood glucose levels.

questions.question: Question 4: Positive feedback is seen in all except
questions.explanation:
Positive feedback is seen in all except gastric secretion. It is under negative feedback control. Negative feedback consists of certain changes that affect a deficient or excessive variable to pull it 
back to a certain mean value to maintain homeostasis. Most processes in the body are under 
negative feedback. For example, an increase in gastric acids leading to a decrease in gastric 
secretion. Positive feedback consists of changes that affect a variable to push it further away from a certain 
mean value. For example, an increase in LH leading to a further increase in LH. Instances, where 
positive feedback plays an important role are: • Clotting of blood • Calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum • LH Surge • Action potential • Shock • Parturition

questions.question:
Question 5: On infusion of a large volume of blood, the MAP rises from 100 mmHg to 175 mmHg. Due to 
the baroreceptor feedback mechanism, the MAP falls down to 125 mmHg. Calculate the gain 
of the feedback system.
questions.explanation:
The gain of the feedback system in the above case is -2. The gain of the system is then calculated by using the following formula: Gain = C/E Here, C is correction achieved from the deviated value and E is the remaining error 
post-correction. Calculation 12 
Sold by @itachibot • The original value in the given case is 100 mmHg. • The deviated value in the given case is 175 mmHg. • The corrected value in the given case is 125 mmHg. • C is given by correction achieved from deviated value, Corrected value - Deviated value = 125 - 
175 = -50 mmHg. • E is given by the remaining error post-correction, Corrected value - Original value = 125 - 100 = 
25 mmHg. • Gain = -50/25 = -2. The negative symbol indicates that the homeostatic mechanism acts in a direction opposite to the 
initial deviation.

questions.question: Question 6: Plasma membrane in eukaryotes is made up of all except
questions.explanation:
Plasma membrane in eukaryotes does not contain triglycerides. The plasma membrane is composed almost entirely of proteins and lipids. The major lipids 
include: • Phospholipids: Lecithin, cephalin, phosphatidylserine • Sphingolipids: Sphingomyelin • Cholesterol

questions.question:
Question 7: Membrane fluidity is increased by  
.
questions.explanation:
Membrane fluidity is increased by linoleic acid, an unsaturated fatty acid. All other options are 
saturated fatty acids. Longer and saturated fatty acids decrease the fluidity because their side chains are straight and 
interact more strongly with each other. Conversely, unsaturated fatty acids increase the 
fluidity because their side chains are kinked and less compact. Cholesterol, also known as fluidity buffer helps to maintain the fluidity of the cell membrane.

questions.explanation:

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 10: The sequence of vesicular transport in a cell is
questions.explanation:
The sequence of vesicular transport in a cell is ER - Cis - Trans - Cell membrane. Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) - It is the site of protein synthesis. Proteins are taken to the 
Golgi apparatus through transport vesicles. Cis end of Golgi apparatus - Also called as receiving end, it is closest to RER Trans end of Golgi apparatus - Also called as releasing end, it is furthest away from RER. Cell membrane - Synthesised proteins within secretory vesicles are released into the extracellular 
space through the process of exocytosis.

questions.question: Question 11: All of the following are enzyme markers of mitochondria except
questions.explanation:
5’ Nucleotidase is an enzyme marker for plasma membrane. All the other options are 
mitochondrial enzyme markers.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following will test negative for all mitochondrial markers?
questions.explanation:
Mature red blood cells will test negative for all mitochondrial markers are as they do not have 
mitochondria. Lack of mitochondria is the reason why red blood cells exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to 
generate ATP.

questions.question: Question 13: Which is the characteristic enzyme present in peroxisome?
questions.explanation:
15 
Sold by @itachibot Catalase is the characteristic enzyme of peroxisomes. All other are lysosomal enzymes.

questions.question: Question 14: Gap junctions are found in all except
questions.explanation:
Gap junctions are absent in adult skeletal muscles. Gap junctions are intercellular connections with a channel in between. They are present in 
excitable tissues such as cardiac muscle, smooth muscle and neurons but not in skeletal muscles.

questions.question:
Question 15: Tight junctions are not seen in  
.
questions.explanation:
Tight junctions are not seen in cardiac muscle. Tight junctions form a water-tight seal between cells. They are characteristically seen in the 
following: • Intestinal mucosa • Renal tubules • Choroid plexus • Sertoli cells Functions of tight junctions are: • Prevents the diffusion of macromolecules between cells. • Maintains cell polarity. • Seals the paracellular pathway. 16 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not a cell adhesion molecule (CAM)?
questions.explanation:
Spectrin is a cytoskeletal protein but not a cell adhesion molecule. Cells are attached to each other or to the basal lamina by cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). Some 
important classes of CAMs are: • Integrins: heterodimers that bind to various receptors • IgG superfamily of immunoglobulins • Cadherins: Ca2+-dependent molecules that mediate cell-to-cell adhesion by homophilic reactions • Selectins which have lectin-like domains that bind carbohydrates Clinical significance • Cancer cells have abnormal CAMs and hence cause decreased cell adhesion and allow individual 
cancer cells to detach from the parent cancer. • The decrease in the amount of E-cadherin maybe the reason for early metastasis of numerous 
tumors.

questions.question: Question 17: Identify the incorrectly matched pair of intercellular connections and their structural units
questions.explanation:
Gap junctions are made of connexons. Connexons are in turn made of units called connexins. The different intercellular connections and their structural units are given below: Intercellular connections 
Structural units Occludins, claudins and junct 
ional adhesion molecules Tight junctions or zona occlu 
dens Gap junctions

Cadherins 17

Cadherins like desmoglein Hemidesmosome 
Integrins

questions.question: Question 18: Integrin connects with:
questions.explanation:
Integrin connects with fibronectin. Integrins are transmembrane glycoproteins (integral proteins) that allow cells to attach to 
extracellular matrix constituents such as laminin, fibronectin and collagen. It helps in linking the 
intracellular cytoskeleton functionally and structurally with the outside world.

questions.question:
Question 19: The force-generating proteins are  
.
questions.explanation:
The force-generating proteins are dynein and kinesin. There are three superfamilies of proteins namely kinesin, dynein, myosin referred to as molecular 
motors. The molecular motors are the force generating proteins as they move proteins, organelles, and 
other cell parts (collectively referred to as “cargo”) to all parts of the cell.

questions.question: Question 20: An absent dynein arm in cilia can lead to all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
An absent dynein arm in cilia leads to primary ciliary dyskinesia. Kartagener syndrome is a 
primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, 
and bronchiectasis. Ciliocytophthoria is the degradation of ciliated cells due to viral infections. It is not seen in 
primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.question:

.
questions.explanation:
Tubulins constitute the microtubules that form the mitotic spindle in a dividing cell. Cytoskeletal elements of the cell. Ubiquitin helps in protein degradation. Cytoskeletal element
